body:
Maybe rename them to something more descriptive?
Or should we close this issue? (due to lack of activity)
Closing due to lack of activity.

The UI has been rewritten, currently it shows a blank page until the js is loaded, which is somewhat ugly, but can be improved later on - in any case, since it's a pure javascript UI this won't be a problem in the future.

Maybe this could be a configuration option, just like default query limit?
The UI refactoring is pretty much done now, so people can send patches.
The logic for this is ported to JavaScript. There are karma tests, so it should be easy enough to add a test that verifies the wanted behavior, and then changes the order of precedence.

One of the problems with the dependencies view today is that it assumes a directed asyclic graph, while introducing haproxy into the mix would create circular dependencies, like in "a -> haproxy -> b -> haproxy -> c".
It assumes a DAG because... nobody would ever introduce cyclic dependencies between microservices... right...?
I'll close this due to lack of activity and disagreement on whether this is the right direction for upstream Zipkin or not.
I'll close this issue - elasticsearch issues should go here: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-scala-elasticsearch
Closing this due to lack of activity - seems like people agree on staying on the old driver version until more people have upgraded to a recent Cassandra version.

Yes, definitely should be a config option, like `maxSpanCountForExpandAll`

I haven't seen the new config mechanism yet, do we have docs on how one can change config options at deployment?

No, unfortunately we're lagging behind on that part :-/ You'll have to hard-code it into the config.json handler for now. (There is one handler in zipkin-query and one in zipkin-web, of course it's temporary that it's duplicated)

Methinks the name describes what the job does pretty well (-pr tests with a merge into `master`, -push tests on the branch). The issue here seems to be that one of the jobs (push) works incorrectly. I'm not sure how to approach fixing this without digging into Travis documentation.

Depending on how you think about GitHub Issues (todo list vs. issue tracker), it may make sense to close this (no-one's been working on this) or keeping it around (let's not forget it's an issue). Personally I'm in the "issue tracker" camp and would keep this open.
I feel the same way. Thanks for cleaning up!
I don't know, and have no easy way of reproducing. I'm +1 for closing (too much effort to even reproduce, didn't seem like anyone else has hit this)
Negative. ATM there are 35 dependencies with no license, 11 of which are other subprojects of `openzipkin/zipkin`.
Negative. 11 subproject dependencies are affected.

it got fixed in one of the recent ui versions. good to close.

Prateek Agarwal

@dsyer FYI, this implements the "rename `static` to `zipkin-ui` in the jar" KISS solution mentioned in https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/pull/98#issuecomment-197453093.
Closed via #1048

> Generates separate index.html for /dependency/

This would break in other cases, e.g. the /trace/:traceId endpoint. And it wouldn't be very forwards-compatible once we add more routes.

on rename of "/static" to "/zipkin-ui" I think this was a nudge to try to use webjar format, which neither are. It probably will help, at the end of the day, and the amount of custom code in zipkin-java doesn't change all that much I think.
ps for things like this, it is kindof more convenient to raise on a openzipkin/zipkin so no need to fetch and pick commits to try it (plus I can contribute there, too)
thx
hehe yeah they do :)

weird.. I thought we had another issue on this same topic (of expand-all). can't find it .. shrug!

I prefer expand-all, too, but maybe the trace detail was designed for query (where you had selected a specific service). go to trace probably should default to expand all, regardless.

heh I think the real lack of activity is about someone doing the work.
latest status was that it doesn't actually limit cassandra versions since
repository is written in CQL. Regardless, I can open it again when this
becomes important.
htrace, not hbase :) Anyway, e2e tests aren't likely to happen in this repo.
irrelevant now, mountains have moved since :)
Moved to shared branch in #1049

@eirslett Indeed, I missed that. Will revert that change.

@adriancole on webjar: I agree it was a nudge in that direction. I don't have a strong opinion on the webjar-vs-not debate, and don't know enough to form one. I'm deferring to @eirslett on this one, I was under the impression we had a consensus.
Ooos, sorry :-P
verified everything works in this repo!

I'm still not convinced we need an assets directory - finatra solves this in zipkin-query quite elegantly, so we could simply forward all HTTP traffic directly from zipkin-web to zipkin-query as-is. (See my comment in #1050)

Agree that if we want to provide zero support for hosting without defaulting to `index.html`, we don't need an assets directory. I'd note that not having an assets subdirectory not only doesn't provide support, but actively makes it harder.
As discussed in #1050, defaulting to `index.html` will be the only supported way of hosting, at the very least for the time being. This means we can remove the assets dir with no consequences.
@eirslett methinks this is ready for final review. Will squash before merge.
The code looks good to me! (but I haven't tested it)
this is a really good idea. one of the problems with kafka is that it is hard to test. with this change, you can literally use the CLI to post a span onto a topic. cc @prat0318 @kristofa
cc @gena01 @eirslett
bin/query looks fine, but bin/web results in an empty screen. If you enter /index.html you get the banner like so.. same issue with the shadowJar
What shows up in the browser debugger? Do you get 404 on any resources? Any console error messages? What is the HTML that is served?

Great work! The code looks good to me! (But I haven't tested it)
Did you try spinning it up manually, with kafka and all?

Oh crap I forgot again. The longer URL rule wins. "/" is longer than "". This was the reason for moving both the index and the static asset handling code into the same handler, and decide which one to serve in there, instead of with routing rules.

Won't be able to write the code today, but wanted to give you a heads up. Sorry :D Also, no idea how I didn't notice this. Should probably just cherry-pick #1051 into this one...

nope.. didn't manually test kafka, but I'm interested enough to do that.
Will paste some goodies tomorrow.

Maybe we should do this more generally, e.g. all zipkin flags should be able to read from environment variables with the same name; e.g. the "zipkin.collector.storage.ttl" should be able to read the environment variable ZIPKIN_COLLECTOR_STORAGE_TTL. That should make it work for all flags - a more generic solution. @adriancole wdyt? Would this require changes in twitter libraries upstream?

Right now, it is nice to know what the hardest hitting properties are, ex that they've been asked for. There are a number of internal properties that have never been modified, and I really don't want to expand the interface or make portability more difficult by locking them in.
works after rebase!

To elaborate :)

I'd like to separate functionality from support policy. Whether or not some library inside twitter.app automagically accepts env variables is a different point than the list of known tested properties.

By supporting a closed set of env properties, backends can work cross-language. Ex. someone writing a collector in go has a limited set of well-known properties they'd need to support. This works today. For example, the closed set of env variables is why you can drop in the java or the scala query server and get the same behavior in docker (service-level abstraction). All of the readmes include a closed set of properties and what they do. I've found a closed set quite helpful when discussing support issues with @prat0318 for example.

On the functionality side, Spring boot does auto-export, but I consider that an internal detail. Ex Some of the names aren't well thought through, or eagerly configurable. If we formally support implicitly defined variables, we'd have a harder time removing or changing them in the future. Sometimes changing them is needed to better design the component. For example, some things keep an internal queue when maybe they shouldn't.

Long story short, if/when finatra could support auto-export, and we could use that feature, I would still want to explicitly call out TTL as a supported feature vs an accident of a flag name. I do find value in such a feature as it could allow us to experiment with not-yet-supported flags easier.

Hope this essay helps :)

PS #1041 would need to be addressed before a flag auto-env-binder would be usable.
PS I'm in favor of letting flags pass through. It would help us reduce dependence on the "scala config" or hopefully remove it.

closed via e01f942f7b3df548f65b272582cbf5470580bb14

nice job

tested with the following things..

In one tab, start up kafka and post a span list to it

``` bash
$ docker run -d -p 2181:2181 -p 9092:9092 --env ADVERTISED_HOST=192.168.99.100  --env AUTO_CREATE_TOPICS=true spotify/kafka
$ kafka-console-producer.sh --broker-list 192.168.99.100:9092 --topic zipkin
[{"traceId":"1","name":"bang","id":"2","timestamp":1234,"binaryAnnotations":[{"key":"lc","value":"bamm-bamm","endpoint":{"serviceName":"flintstones","ipv4":"127.0.0.1"}}]}]
```

In two tabs, run the query and the collector:

``` bash
$ bin/query
# in a separate tab, as query cannot consume kafka, yet...
$ KAFKA_ZOOKEEPER=192.168.99.100:2181 bin/collector
```

Finally, curl and see the span arrived!

``` bash
$ curl -s localhost:9411/api/v1/trace/1
[{"traceId":"0000000000000001","name":"bang","id":"0000000000000002","timestamp":1234,"annotations":[],"binaryAnnotations":[{"key":"lc","value":"bamm-bamm","endpoint":{"serviceName":"flintstones","ipv4":"127.0.0.1"}}]}]
```

Due to the nature of scala-config, this is hard to automatically test. I ran tests manually by passing variables to bin/collector and bin/query with debug logging on.

Ex. 

``` bash
$ COLLECTOR_LOG_LEVEL=debug CASSANDRA_SPAN_TTL=1 CASSANDRA_INDEX_TTL=2 bin/collector cassandra
```

I'd probably leave a couple weeks, maybe a month "deprecation period". Or alternately define the list of projects we want to make sure migrate to `zipkin-web`-less before deleting it fully. Is that taking things too slowly? (This would mean reordering the steps, providing migration documentation first and deprecation notices, then later removing stuff)
Yes, that sounds like a better idea!

Yeap. We should probably summarize an email to zipkin-user about this
wonderful progress
I suspect this _may_ be caused by one ore more spans that either miss timestamp or duration. Could that be right? You can see the raw JSON data in the chrome debugger by inspecting the network call.

Wish there was a way to send a pull-request to the description of an issue. How about this:

## Deprecation
- [x] Make zipkin-web a dumb proxy
- [ ] Provide a migration guide for people who run zipkin-query + zipkin-web today
- [ ] Make deprecation workflow explicit; when (time or version) will zipkin-web go away fully?
- [ ] Add deprecation notice to 
  - [ ] zipkin.io?
  - [ ] zipkin README
  - [ ] docker-zipkin README
  - [ ] zipkin-web documentation
  - [ ] Startup messages of zipkin-web
- [ ] Announce deprecation to zipkin-user, zipkin-dev, downstream projects (mesos, what else?)

## Removal
- [ ] Remove the zipkin-web submodule from Gradle
- [ ] Remove references to zipkin-web in documentation (architecture)
- [ ] Release new Zipkin artifacts
- [ ] Deprecate the zipkin-web docker image
- [ ] Remove zipkin-web from docker-zipkin, expose zipkin-query on the old port of zipkin-web
- [ ] Announce removal to same parties as for deprecation

One thing to bear in mind here is that I don't think we've ever raised here is some UI changes imply cementing in aspects of the zipkin data model, which aren't universally popular and may limit future model choices.

For example, the binary annotation data structure is not popular. There exists a sentiment that they could be simpler, ex a String->String map. If we formally support reporting the originating host of a binary annotations, this limits model options to those that intentionally allow repeats. [Zipkin v2](#939) could solve this, if it stays single-host spans. If it doesn't, and a String->String map was chosen, then changing the UI to report the origin of a tag wouldn't be supportable.

This situation is not new, by the way, just solving it hasn't proved popular. Even here, multiple folks are working around this as opposed to asking for this to be changed. Ex filtering duplicates, or they have adjusted their tracers to avoid the ambiguity. Personally, I'm happy about that, as the act of "choosing" on conflict for most fields, particularly span name, has proven high-maintenance code. Leaving that undefined for routine binary annotations is less code to maintain.

Since the time we introduced zipkin's http api, one could troubleshoot any issue like this by looking at the json for the trace. In fact, I noticed in a screen shot that Uber actually have "json" UI element, which could make navigation even easier. I'd recommend we sit on this and consider it for zipkin v2 vs investing further time into this topic, as rehashing this hurts the project by displacing time.

In the mean time, we might want to formalize a UI element to make getting to the raw json easier.
very subtle, but the issue isn't about null, rather undefined. A span that has timestamp set, but duration undefined causes this. Will adjust the PR

OK rewrote implementation after finding a span that could cause this. When zipkin-java updates to and passes latest span store tests, this won't likely be possible. At any rate, the problem is dangerous, so we should leave the check in.

Slightly confused here. Both Annotation and BinaryAnnotation have an optional Endpoint field (going by https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-thrift/src/main/thrift/com/twitter/zipkin/zipkinCore.thrift). Why not add that as a column to the UI?

I'm over quota rehashing this, but trying again.

binaryannotation.host is sometimes set, so yes when it is present the UI
could display it.

That display choice will cost code, for example whether to log the same
pair twice when values agree or not. This type of code often breaks.

Others have mentioned on this thread that they filter out duplicates, just
like we do now. Also, knowing the host is a special case. Even if a feature
is possible to make, that doesn't mean we should.

Finally, if we do this and choose to make the model use string-string tags
(which dont include host) as discussed in the past, we will break the
feature.

Regardless, it is so unpopular that it doesn't deserve this kind of
attention. Either someone should implement it in a supportable way, or
close it. No free lunch

Shorter why not:

Widening the UI from key-value to (key, value, host) causes the following.
- Clutter for those who perceive tags as unique per key. Ex multiple rows
  saying http.method=GET for each host
- More code to maintain if we choose to be less cluttery (ex suppress on
  identical key/value, etc)
- More difficult decisions later, especially around data structures to
  represent tags. This is what i am moat concerned with.

Right now, the path is clear as "binary annotation" and all its complexity
isn't presented to the user in a way that would prevent us from moving to
plain string-string.

As both someone who often has to fix bugs in code like this, yet also one
interested in actually improving our model to prevent them.. I really don't
like this feature as it will almost certainly cause burden for very little
gain.
Got it. Thanks for the explanation; with those in mind, it does sound like the effort outweighs the gain for now.
Thanks for thinking it through.. Bus factor increase!
Yep missing duration was it.

elasticsearch is being very quickly implemented here. It may move to the above repo at some point, probably with a different name as no scala is involved https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/pull/107
there was a mention about more powerful query with elasticsearch. this is an FYI that elasticsearch is nearing completion here: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/pull/107
old issue, but fyi elasticsearch is being implemented here: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/pull/107
releasing a subminor as this bug hits very hard when present
released in 1.38.1 please give it a shot!
Thank you for fixing this. It's loading now and seems a bit faster. I guess there's no duration if both timestamps match?

They're definitely supposed to be cached.
If you look at ZipkinQueryController, you could try doing something like this (pseudocode):

``` scala
import com.twitter.conversions.time._ // To get the "10.minutes" syntax sugar
// ...
get("/:*") { request: Request =>
    val resp = response.ok.fileOrIndex(
    request.params("*"),
    "index.html"
    )

    resp.cacheControl = 10.minutes
    resp
  }
```

If it works, and you're in the mood for a PR... well... :wink:

About setting charset=utf-8 when the content type is image/png; that seems more like a bug in Finatra, so it should probably be filed as an issue there.

No duration if span.duration wasnt set by instrumentation and any of the
following are true:
- there are no annotations
- all annotations have the same timestamp
- there's a bug in the server ;)
Should i open a separate bug on Last-Modified/If-Modified-Since being missing as well?

I would say they belong to the same issue.
In the long term, we should set something like 1 minute timeout on index.html, and 1 year timeout on the assets - given that we add hashes to the asset names. I think we can do that with webpack.
If you cd zipkin-ui and npm run dev, will it still work? Live-reload etc.?

:O Why would that change? Checking...

Edit: oh I see, not sure that filename changes are picked up by live reload. Still checking.

With `npm run dev` the site doesn't load, I get a bad gateway for config.json. Assuming it wants to proxy to zipkin-web (makes sense), so I did `./gradlew zipkin-web:run`. But zipkin-web gives me a 500 with this unhelpful message in the console:

```
E 0322 16:31:25.350 THREAD21: Exception propagated to the root monitor!
com.twitter.finagle.FailedFastException: Endpoint zipkin-web is marked down. For more details see: https://twitter.github.io/finagle/guide/FAQ.html#why-do-clients-see-com-twitter-finagle-failedfastexception-s
    at com.twitter.finagle.NoStacktrace(Unknown Source)
```

This is on `master` on a clean build. Unfortunately I'm out of time to spend on this ATM; if you can quickly verify that this PR works, that's much appreciated. Otherwise I'll have more time tonight.

Try starting zipkin-query instead of zipkin-web?
And it looks like the documentation is outdated, too...
The "Developing" section must be moved from zipkin-web/README.md to zipkin-ui/README.md.
And we need to update webpack.config.js so that it proxies to port 9411 (the query server directly) instead of 8080 (web).
But I tested this change, it works with livereload!

I feel embarrassed we haven't had the time to push up our ES implementation yet. If you guys are close then it might be worth closing off the scala repo.
good idea.. just nuked it, as agreed it would be confusing to others.
indeed. thanks!

Personally, I've always disliked it when websites open tabs without being asked to. It breaks the default behavior of the browser and user expectations. Here's a good summary with many references: http://libux.co/links-should-open-in-the-same-window/

A user can always choose to open a new tab via middle-click or Cmd-click.
I agree with @yurishkuro here. Right-click and open in a new tab.
Thx for speaking up, folks!
It should be possible to add this in trace.mustache, I think. Something like `JSON`

there's something to consider in the above logic, which is how to detect if we are serving the content of index.html or not. if we are just going on the path name, it is simpler.

```
resp.cacheControl =  if (isIndex) 365.days else 1.minute
```
Let's go for the path name, but the opposite ;) no caching for api, 1 minute caching for index, 10 minutes for config, 1 year for everything else?
opened #1062 with a work-in-progress. If anyone feels like adding commits, go for it!
I believe the query REST API accepts a `lookback` parameter, it's just not exposed in the UI.

a good UI widget for lookback would be the way Grafana2 does it. I wonder if it's available somewhere in reusable form.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3523016/14037177/3e26d4e4-f217-11e5-9556-be3f59f73fd5.png)
a quick could be to port the code from the dependencies screen that already does this. This should be very easy as the query parameters are the same (ex endTs and lookback) cc @t-yuki
Is it implemented in the API backends yet?
